Service should seek to regulate job descriptions as much as possible and
have accurate knowledge concerning classification and probable salary ranges

In line with this thought, the Placement Service has recently taken steps
with regard to accomplishing classification and descriptions.
classification
The first step in establishing a classification of educational broadcasting
personnel was the drafting of a temporary classification list. The Place¬
ment Officer, with the generous assistance of NAEB officials, devised such
a list. This list, accompanied by a form letter requesting that appropriate
entries be made on spaces provided on the list, and further requesting that
the list be returned to the Placement Service, was sent to all active and
associate members of the NAEB. (This form letter, hereafter referred to as
Form Letter II, and the accompanying list may be found in Appendix C.)
At this time, the Placement Service has received an approximate twenty per
cent (2C$) response to this request. It is felt that this response is not
sufficient to warrant the undertaking of the final tabulation and distribu¬
tion of results. Therefore, it is strongly recommended that those who have
not responded be urged to do so as soon as possible. A step in this direction
was taken in the March, 1955 Newsletter Supplement. (See Appendix D.)
DESCRIPTIONS
Form Letter II contains a paragraph wherein is described the extreme import¬
ance of descriptions and an urgent request is made that if the employer has
any available he forward a copy of them to the Placement Service, At this
time only a few such descriptions have been received mainly, it is felt,
because employers do not have such descriptions available.
It is recommended that inquiries be made as to how the Placement Service can
receive some type of job descriptions. It is possible that the Placement
Service could contact commercial radio and television broadcasters and
inquire as to their willingness to cooperate with us; or perhaps the Place¬
ment Service could contact other personnel services or agencies to discover
their means of obtaining these necessary job descriptions. (See Appendix E)
It is strongly urged that these descriptions be obtained in the near future,
for without them the Placement Service is unable to give one hundred per
cent service.
SUMMARY
The importance of obtaining these classifications and descriptions has been
stressed. The original intention of the Placement Service was to have the
results tabulated and distributed by April 1, 1955* However, in the light
of the response received, this tabulation and distribution will have to be
delayed for some time. When an adequate number of responses have been
received, it shall be the duty of the Placement Officer to tabulate and
